@jlucky13 The longest running yield curve inversion I know of is the 10Y-1Y spread. That one dates back to the 60s. 
 
Any dip below the zero line is an inversion. That's the warning. The steepening is when the line moves back up out of negative territory into positive territory again. This happens as short term rates fall and recession takes hold. $SPY goes down, even back in the late 60s and 70s, if it existed then. 
 
Is there a better bearish stock indicator for the market? Is there a better recession indicator out there? 
 
If there is, I don't know it.

#4 Today. Stocks bottomed in October, or so every bull tells me. But what does the yield curve say? 
 
Dark red is the 'October bottom'. Does that look like a normal yield curve to you, as we saw during every stock market bottom the past 20 years? 
 
Nope. In October the curve was still messed up/flat. It's even more messed up/inverted today. 
 
And this is why I don't buy the argument that the stock market has bottomed. I don't care how high liquidity can pump it. The bond market still says something is deeply wrong here. And it's been right every other time. 
 
In addition, the re-steepening of the yield curve is when the sell-off in stocks has been most severe in every prior cycle. Last year was a terrible bear market, but there was no re-steepening of the curve. And this MUST happen. Because inverted curves are not a stable state for bonds. 
 
Bull markets require a normal slope in the yield curve. $STUDY the animated chart.

$SPY $QQQ $TLT $TMF $STUDY  
 
I discovered Stockcharts has an animated yield curve going back 20 years, and it's awesome. You can watch the shape of the yield curve change from normal, to flat, to inverted and see how stocks react: 
 
stockcharts.com/freecharts/... 
 
We're inverted right now, and following inversion in the bond market is something called the bull-steepening phase for bonds, where the yield curve goes back to a normal, upward slope as short-term interest rates fall again. 
 
You can see this by watching the curve after the dotcom, GFC and covid peaks. The left side (short term rates) crashes to the floor. This necessary phase is always bad for stocks. But once the curve is "normal" again, then you get your market bottom in stocks. 
 
Here's some examples. 
 
#1: Dot com. Note that the curve (dark red) is inverted at the top of the market, and at the bottom of the market (light red) is normal again.

The market is now pricing stocks and corporate credit with the same return as a risk-free 3 month treasury bill. This is the shaky ground this current bull market is built upon. 
 
If you want to see what happens when the market starts pricing in risk, look at 2020. Risk-free treasury yields collapsed, while risky IG and S&P yields soared. IE, $LQD, $HYG and $SPY crashed while $TLT, $IEF, etc. soared. 
 
With yield spreads this tight, there is virtually no risk (or risk premia) priced into the market. It's insane. 
 
The coming spread blowout/correction in credit markets will be incredible. You won't see it in your elliot wave analysis so good luck with that.

@FTV This reminds me of something I witnessed this weekend. I was at a blackjack table and a guy to my left was a pro. He could give you rough odds on any given hand. 
 
A lady sits down, we'll call her Karen. Karen is obviously new. Seeing how well the pro is doing, Karen starts asking for advice. She gets dealt a pair of 8s. Pro tells Karen he would split those 8s. Dealer nods, so she goes for it. She gets 18 and something else. Dealer gets 20 and she loses. 
 
Karen then gets pissed at the pro who gave her the advice, even though his advice was correct. But Karen thinks the pro should win every hand, which is not at all realistic. 
 
Point is, whether gambling or trading, don't be a Karen.

Back in summer of 2008, right before the financial crisis really kicked off, the Fed was worried about inflation. They were already in the process of cutting rates, and still there was talk about a need to reverse and hike according to historical, closed-door transcripts which are released 5 years after the FOMC meetings. 
 
Even at the end of a business cycle when the economy has entered recession and inflation falls, they were still focused on inflation. Just a few weeks later Lehman failed, and they cut rates further. 
 
And no, I'm not saying this is 2008 again. I'm saying if you're expecting this clueless bunch to alert you to something like that ahead of time, think again.

$TLT will underperform $SPY in the long term. When risk-free treasuries outperform risky investments, something is terribly wrong in the market. That shouldn't be the norm. 
 
Bonds are a trade for this environment, specifically the deepest inverted yield curve in 40 years, and LEIs near covid lows. These indicators are rare, and have a 100% accuracy rate. It's only happened 4 times since 2000. Dotcom, GFC, covid, NOW. 
 
That, and I know bull steepening in the bond curve is inevitable and will send stocks lower. Again - 100% hit rate as the inverted curve unkinks itself and the Fed cuts rates. 
 
I could hype bullish technicals, like every other bull because all they do is TA. It's useful, but it's not 100% accurate. LEIs and yield curves are 100%. So I have my money on that. 
 
Most people don't know or care about any of this. They don't see the underlying risk, they just see equities rally after a bad year and assume the financial system is ok now.

Something worth watching is confirmation for a peak in "rent of primary residence". This put in its first lower YoY print in April. 
 
Why does it matter? Because "rent of primary residence" is about 30% of Core CPI and 20% of Core CPE and it went to the moon. This 400lb gorilla is what has fueled the "sticky inflation" narrative for months now. 
 
Real-time market data has been forecasting this laggy beast to turn, which will put downward pressure on core inflation metrics into 2H of this year, upending the last bastion of the inflationistas. 
 
The real threat ahead is deflation and a 'credit crunch', as Powell had pounded rate hikes like a 21 year old pounding birthday shots at a bar. 
 
As a result, the bond market is still expecting the economy to get shit-faced. And the stock market is blissfully unaware the economy is its designated driver.

Here's an update on my Net Liquidity tradingview script. I haven't posted about this lately. 
 
As you can see, since last October net liquidity has drifted upward along with the market. The TGA (in red) has dwindled down to almost nothing headed into the debt ceiling. Now that the ceiling has been lifted, Yellen will start refilling government coffers this week. So far $161 billion has been announced. 
 
So what happens to liquidity? Bulls say the liquidity will be pulled from reverse repo in yellow, leaving green unaffected. Participants who have cash parked at the Fed will use it to buy all these T-bills. 
 
Bears say reverse repo isn't going to drain, and instead red will grow at the expense of green as banks use their reserves and other funds to buy these bills/lend to government. 
 
I don't know who will be right. But this is something to watch this month, as the liquidity model has proven more accurate than even I expected.

Even if you're bearish as I am, I still would not buy $UVXY or $VXX. Unless you are an expert at day trading or swing trading these products, you will get crushed. 
 
Everyone has pointed out they're mechanically designed go down over time. So in essence you're stuck trying to catch a dead cat bounce in a permanent downtrend. Look at this log chart for an example. 
 
Rather than shorting the market, or longing the $VIX hoping for a spike, you're better off allocating to bonds like $TLT or $TMF. This is the whole idea behind the 60/40 portfolio. The largest $VIX spikes happen in recession which is when yields fall and bonds soar. 
 
The best money in $UVXY and $VXX is to short a $VIX spike after it happens, not get long and try to anticipate the spike. Less guessing involved. 
 
And FWIW, yes I think another big $VIX spike is coming when corporate credit spreads blow out again during another "credit event". But it's impossible to put a date on it.

Here's 5 decades of initial jobless claims vs the S&P 500. 
 
Many are saying recession is over/not happening because stock indices have recovered. In a normal cycle that would be true, as bear markets typically overlap recessions. So you get a washout in stocks along with a washout in the economy. But that didn't happen last year. Stocks washed out but the labor market remained strong. 
 
Since September of last year initial claims have been rising along with the market, which is unusual. You can see the divergence on this chart. (note that initial claims are flipped upside down) 
 
This current recovery will likely prove be a massive bull-trap as jobless claims continue to rise, which is what follows higher interest rates in every prior business cycle.

$TLT $TMF - if you're wondering why it's up, it's because initial jobless claims came in hotter than expected by +24k. 
 
This is all that matters for bonds over the coming months. And it will cause fierce short covering to the waterfall selling happening in futures ($ZB_F & $UB_F).

@Mellow2022 Primarily bills, but I haven't seen the auction schedule and sizing yet. 
 
I keep seeing people say rates will go up due to a massive amount of bill supply issued. History doesn't support that. Short term rates like a 3 month bill or Fed Funds Rate follow SOFR. Notice how SOFR declined as bills were issued in 2019 and then went to zero in 2020? Issuance doesn't drive yields. 
 
When banks buy gov debt, their reserve/cash balance falls while the treasury's balance increases. It's basically a cash swap from two different balance sheets, which in theory represents the liquidity drain. An imbalance in either cash or collateral can send overnight borrowing rates higher. 
 
Anyway, here's the same chart with $TLT. Bonds rallied through 2019 and into 2020 as rates were cut and the TGA refilled. We got a typical recessionary peak/blow off top in bonds, then bear market we've been in. 
 
Risk off/recession bid to bonds is more important than TGA refill IMO.

$SPY $QQQ $TLT $STUDY 
 
Let's look back at 2019. Powell's first rate cut of the prior cycle came in July 2019. He also stopped QT. Two weeks later the debt ceiling was lifted and treasury started refilling its coffers, $200 billion in the first month. Following that we got the repo crisis, which forced the NY Fed to inject money into the market. Liquidity was scarce due to quarterly corporate taxes coming due and the issuance of treasury bills to fill the TGA. 
 
In December 2021 the debt limit was raised again and the TGA jumped nearly $500 billion in January 2022. $SPY peaked and bear market began. This pattern lends credibility to fears of liquidity problems as the government refills its bank account. 
 
Debt ceiling will likely get voted on this Wednesday. Marjorie Taylor Green tweeted suggesting they'll cut spending in future appropriations. So if that side of the GOP is relenting, the ceiling may pass without any voting drama.

This chart provides an interesting perspective on markets. Tail events are where you make the most money. What's funny is one tail (bubble) usually leads to the other (crash), even though both conditions are on their own relatively rare. 
 
This chart is also why I like Bollinger Bands. BBs use standard deviations to plot a normal range of price behavior (where prices should normally fall given prior history). So if prices move outside the bands you know price is "tailing" too far up or down over a given time frame and can play the mean reversion to the other side. 
 
Playing the reversal of a 2 or 3 standard deviation move in price is generally a good bet.

@Vkvk I suppose one big difference is companies can suspend their dividend payments, so the dividend yield isn't a guarantee. Many oil companies did this after oil crashed and they struggled to handle their debt load. Companies would much rather eliminate/cut divies or dilute equity holders to service debt and avoid default. 
 
Also if you hold a bond to maturity and there's no default, you'll get your money back. Some stocks never recover. So there's that aspect. 
 
$HYG yielded around 4.5% last year while $SPY yielded around 1.5%. Both had about the same beta or volatility. 
 
We should see corporate bankruptcies rise as junk debt is forced to refinance at higher rates, or gets flushed with recession. Then corporate yields will rise and equities will price lower. 
 
$IEF -0.3% today while $LQD was flat. Corporates rallying against treasuries = stocks up. 
 
That trend won't last. The spread between treasuries and corporate credit hasn't been this tight since 2006 and 1989.

@Vkvk Stock and bonds have more similarities than differences. You can get the same capital appreciation in bonds by buying them cheap when yields are high as you can in stock. 
 
But higher yield generally = higher risk. That goes for high dividend stocks too. Those are sometimes value traps. 
 
Oil stocks had incredible dividend yields after oil crashed in 2020 and those stocks got cheap. $XOM for example was at $32/share in Nov 2020 with a 9%+ dividend yield. That dropped to just over 3% recently as the stock climbed to $115. 
 
As asset prices recover yields fall. Both stock and bonds. 
 
So hunting for high yields is a pretty good strategy, assuming the entity in question is financially sound. Then you're just buying at a discount. It's why I like treasuries right now, because I don't think these yields will last. In recession corporate yields often jump while government yields fall, creating the spike in my chart above. Look at 2020. 
 
I wouldn't own $JNK, $HYG or $LQD just yet.

A look back on treasury bond yields, short term vs long term in the prior 2 debt ceiling fights. Though we had a 16 day government shutdown in 2013, it doesn't seem to get nearly as much attention as the 2011 fight. Maybe it's because the 2011 budget act gave us Sequestration, which were automatic budget cuts in the federal government. Stock market didn't like that and dumped during the 2011 fight. It went up during the 2013 fight. 
 
Anyway - short term yields spiked UP into both 'crises' as you would expect, as investors were not bidding bonds at risk of 'default'. Long term yields (represented by 10 year) trended down a bit. We're seeing the same thing now in short term yields as 1 month T-bill shot up to 5.9% overnight, which is a couple hikes above where they should be.

There's been talk of recession for nearly a year now.

So is it even happening? Eric Basmajian put out a great research piece covering this: 
 
epbresearch.com/historical-...  
 
In short, leading economic indicators (LEIs) turned negative last June, the same month the 10Y - 2Y yield curve inverted. That's when recession talk began. 
 
Typically it only takes a few months for cyclical (manufacturing and construction) to follow LEIs. We're pushing 11 months now (see chart) probably due to covid creating a construction backlog. So this cycle is taking a LONG time to flush. But construction and manufacturing is already "below trend" (2% growth), and should turn negative in either April or May's data according to EPB research.

OPEC announced a surprise 1Mbpd output cut. Futures gapped up +$5/barrel on this news which is remarkable, likely a short squeeze. 
 
The narrative is that cuts are bullish for oil prices, but are they? I spent a couple hours putting together a chart of OPEC's history of hikes and cuts. 
 
Historically OPEC cuts as prices fall in a weak market. The largest cuts have all occurred during recessions. OPEC has been increasing their output targets by 0.4mbpd each month since August 2021 as oil rallied. Oil peaked in June 2022 and rolled over. By fall 2022 OPEC stopped hiking and started cutting. 
 
OPEC hikes in bull markets and cuts in bear markets. Hikes mean demand is strong, so they feel safe raising output without worrying about falling prices. Cuts are the opposite. They cut back in November and oil prices are lower. 
 
But that doesn't stop fintwit from getting carried away with another "paradigm shift" about how bullish this is.

The way yield curve inversion "fixes" itself is for short term rates to fall below long term rates. All yields will fall (bonds rally), which we're starting to see, but when the Fed cuts rates short term should fall below long term and the curve steepens. This is called a "bull steepener" in bonds. 
 
Look at what's happening, and note for instance the gap closing between the 2 year and 10 year bond as the 2 year collapses to catch up with the 10 year.

You can see this relationship in the chart below. Both the inflection up when the market topped in January of 2022, and the inflection down in October which kicked off this rally. 
 
Note that "financial conditions" in this case is the yield spread between corporate (risky) and treasury (risk-free) bonds. During "credit events" this spread blows out. Typically people sell corporate bonds and buy treasuries, which causes corp yields to surge and treasury yields to fall, sending that $IEF/$LQD line below straight vertical with a stock market crash. That's probably worth its own thread. 
 
People often say "what is $TLT doing" because they know treasuries are a risk-off signal. The better signal is what are treasuries ($IEF in this case) doing in relation to corporate bonds. When treasuries start relatively outperforming corp bonds, stocks go lower and vice versa.

So we've come full circle. What's the takeaway? As the Fed cuts, or treasury yields fall, corporate yields typically surge, causing spreads to blow out and the stock market to crash or go down depending upon how quickly financial conditions tighten. 
 
Ironic isn't it? Especially given so many people talking about wanting cuts. The good news is after this happens we generally have a true market bottom. That's why cuts are bullish, ultimately and why you should always buy a high $VIX (I prefer 35+). 
 
During dotcom spreads gradually widened and financial conditions slowly tightened, so the market didn't crash, just gradually rolled over in that bear market. Basically what we saw throughout 2022. 
 
If the spread remains tight (loose conditions) as treasury yields fall during cuts, stocks should do ok...

🧵 6/8 
 
In fact, the stock market (represented here with $SPY) is just a mirror of the $IEF/$LQD spread, or BofA corporate bond spread. When these spreads blow out, financial conditions tighten and the market goes down. 
 
If there was a way to accurately predict these credit spreads, you would know which way to bet on the market and the $VIX.

Quick reminder as the press and some analysts are now declaring a new bull market in the Nasdaq, since it's up 20% off the lows (in just 2 weeks!). 
 
Look at the candles. Bull markets grind up, they don't panic buy. Panic buyers come from shorts. They're not opening positions, they're desperately buying to close existing shorts as a stop loss. 
 
If you're long into a short squeeze, congrats, you've made great money off someone else's misfortune - the same way bears make money off market crashes when too many people are long and panic sell as a stop loss. 
 
It's generally a bad idea to FOMO into panic moves, whether selling after a crash or buying after a gap up. Wait for a pullback if you really want to own it.

I won't rehash that. But I do want to add a note to imports and exports as I've talked about those. Net Exports were up again as both imports and exports continued the decline into Q4, but imports fell faster so it was a "positive" boost to GDP via net exports. 
 
Historically, declining imports and exports aren't a great sign of economic strength. We run trade deficits (we import more than we export) so typically net exports only jump when import demand is weak. Consumer spending is the majority of GDP, and it was positive in Q4, but down from Q3. Likely more slowing consumer growth is ahead in Q1. 
 
Plateauing or declining import/export figures are common at the end of rate hiking cycles and the start of recessions. But supposedly the FOMC brain-trust isn't done hiking yet.

$TLT Strong 20 year auction today, which is impressive considering 20 year bonds are the redheaded stepchild of the treasury market (10s and 30s are more popular). 
 
TLT is only comprised of 30 year bonds, bought at different times for an average duration of 20+ years. 
 
This zerohedge article won't make any sense unless you know the auction jargon. So I'll break it down. 
 
Treasury auctions work like dutch auctions, the yield starts low and moves higher until the supply is sold and the auction stops. 
 
When Issued - this is where the market expects the auction to stop. When the high yield comes in lower than the WI, the auction "stops through" because demand was strong. When yields run higher than WI this is called a tail. 
 
The bid to cover (BTC) is how many bids were offered vs. amount of debt issued. This was a ~$12 billion auction with ~$34 billion in bids. 34/12 = 2.83. 
 
Indirects = mostly foreigners 
 
Keep in mind The Fed didn't buy anything here.

This thread is inspired by a conversation I had on stocktwits recently. I've put together some original research/data with multiple charts and scenarios which will demonstrate how this is possible. 
 
Background: The Consumer Price Index starts with a base of 100 beginning in 1982. Points get added each month as prices go up. This index always trends up, with rare occasions where it dips. 
 
The entire inflation debate is on the RATE of increase in the CPI. When the media says "inflation is at 7%" they're referring to a YoY comparison of figures. This comparison relies heavily on the base effect, which I'll discuss, as it's important. 
 
I've divided the CPI into specific periods to capture recent trend changes in the index. 
 
Green: 12 months (2020) 
Orange: 18 months (2021- 1H of 2022) 
Pink: Past 6 months (2H of 2022) 
Blue: Example forecast 1H of 2023

@NumberWang @mikeharrisNY The more you push the timeline out, the bigger the number. A 5 year ROC in the late 70s gives you a 60% inflation rate by 1980. 
 
This isn't useful in any practical sense. If anything the 12 month rate of change which is the official measurement is laggy enough. You don't even need to do the math, you can simply look at the index numbers themselves and see the consumer price index hasn't moved since last summer. 
 
All that's left is for those lower numbers on the left to drop out of the calculation and the headline number will fall. 
 
Inflation will be at 2% by this June if the overall price index is at 302 or lower, which is quite a bit higher from here, simply because of the base effect. 
 
302 (June 2023) - 296.311 (June 2022) = 5.689 / 296.311 = 0.19% * 100 = 1.91% inflation rate 
 
That's the CPI calculation.

Bonds rallied this week which sent the yield inversion even lower. 
 
The 10 year - 3 month inversion continues to set new record lows, while the 10 year - 2 year continues to plumb depths not seen since the early 80s. 
 
When the Fed hikes short term rates, it anchors short term yields like the 3 month and 2 year higher, while long-term market-controlled yields like the 10 year+ eventually move lower (pricing in lower growth+inflation). The difference is where you get the negative, inverted number. Inversion is caused by the Fed fixing short term rates. 
 
Notice how when they hike (green line) the curve moves towards inversion, and when it turns negative the Fed typically stops, or cuts. Volcker was more stubborn in the 80s and continued to hike, but even he had to reverse as this👇always causes economic problems. 
 
Unless you're a boomer you haven't lived through what the Fed is doing to the bond market. So pay attention. It's not usually this interesting.

$SPY $QQQ The NYSE New High - New Low moving average is a good indicator of where market strength lies. 
 
When the DMA trends mostly above the zero dotted mark, price momentum is bullish. When it trends below the zero mark, momentum is bearish. In bear markets you'll typically only see short-covering rallies come back up to the mid line before selling off again. This happened in 2016, 2019 and most of last year. 
 
You can also use this indicator for shorter term trades. Buying the market when the average breaks below 200 is good for a swing trade. Even in a down-trend you can buy the trough in the MA and go long with pretty good results.

Oil futures update - contango continues. Since futures curves change over time, shown is a snapshot of each curve at the beginning of the month going back to last July. 
 
Backwardation, where the curve is really steep and pointing up is bullish. Look at July 2022 in purple when WTI prices were over $100/barrel. 
 
Contango, where the curve is really steep and pointing down is bearish. You can see this in the bottom left hand corner in spring 2020 when covid hit and oil crashed.

There's a lot of data indicating EPS will drop into next year (see chart), which would trigger a higher PE ratio for the stock market. What we've seen this year is the stock market unable to support higher PEs as bond yields have gone up, since higher rates/yields devalue future cash flows. Value stocks outperform growth in a rising rate environment for this reason. 
 
So if earnings decline, stock prices have to decline with it to keep PEs from rising. The only thing I know of which could change this equation is a drop in bond yields, which historically allows for higher PE ratios (cheap money = expensive market/assets). 
 
To sum up, if earnings drop and bond yields don't also drop to offset it, I don't see how you can get a new bull market. I also don't see how the lows for stocks are already in under this situation, certainly not if bond yields haven't peaked.

Here's a lesser known indicator which has historically nailed the end of Fed rate hikes. 
 
🟢Green line = Fed Funds Rate/EFFR 
🔵Blue Line = 2 Year Bond Yield 
🔴Red Line = 2 Year Forward Rate Hence 
 
What is the forward rate hence? It's basically the Fed's (very complicated) model of where the market sees the future rate/yield of that given bond. Kind of like a future rate. 
 
Every time the 2 year hence drops below the 2 year spot yield (red line falls below blue line), the 2 year bond yield has moved lower and the Fed has paused hiking. Jeffrey Gundlach argues the Fed simply follows the 2 year with rate policy. So when it peaks, rates have peaked. Fed Funds never goes higher than the 2 year. 
 
This crossover has worked since 1990 and triggered on November 10, when we got that lower than expected CPI report.

As bond yields cycle up (and bond returns increase) this becomes a competitive problem for stocks. Stocks either need to outperform on the earnings side (late 90s is a good example here as yields were moving up) or more commonly, interest rates are cut by the Fed which causes yields to fall (bonds soar in price) and then stocks are relatively more attractive again under the TINA principle (there is no alternative). 
 
S&P earnings haven't been this weak since Q3 2020, so stocks really need bond yields to fall. Higher borrowing costs + higher returns for lenders (bond holders) are both fundamentally bad for attracting capital into the stock market. 
 
Bear market likely to continue until yields come in, which will happen when the Fed cuts rates.

Here's a chart outlining where headline CPI inflation will go into next year depending on month over month figures. 
 
We've averaged 1.6% the past 3 months. If that continues, we'll be at 5% CPI in the next 3 or 4 months, and at 2% inflation by next summer. Why is this significant? The market has already priced in fed hikes to 5% out into Q1 of next year, shown in the red box. The Fed won't hike above CPI. 
 
Furthermore, this chart only factors in -0.1% through 0.7% inflation. Could inflation fall faster? Yes. 
 
During the covid recession in March, April and May of 2020 CPI came in at -0.3%, -0.8% and -0.1% deflation. During the financial crisis, October, November and December of 2008 we had -0.9%, -1.8% and -0.8% respectively. Recessions are deflationary. The Fed was cutting rates during these periods. 
 
A couple big deflationary prints would radically alter the path of Fed policy and CPI. So watch the monthly prints.

$SPY $QQQ $TLT  
 
We had a 10-3 month bond inversion this week. Every time in history the Fed stopped hiking with this inversion, even with inflation at 8.5% in 1982 under Paul Volcker. 
 
10-3 inversions don't last long, as the fed starts easing to fight imminent recession and unwinds the inversion in the process. Here's how it works. 
 
As the Fed hikes, short term yields (teal) move up, eventually overtaking long term yields (orange) which causes dark blue line to move below zero (inversion). 
 
Recession soon follows, long-end bond yields fall (orange), and short-end yields which track Fed Funds (teal) fall even faster as the Fed starts cutting rates, which sends dark blue line back up. 
 
For you pros, that is the "bull steepener" phase of the bond cycle. Bonds will "crash" to the upside as we enter that phase. 
 
Michael Burry nearly went bankrupt shorting housing because he was initially too early, even though he was right. So be patient while the market is irrational.

$SPY $QQQ $TLT repo market is looking dicey again. 
 
For those of you who don't know what this is, picture a $4 trillion pawn shop where upwards of 80% of the pawned items are treasuries. 
 
Money market funds and asset managers who have lots of cash sitting around can lend that overnight to people who need it - banks, hedge funds, market makers, etc. In return for cash these borrowers post collateral, like a giant margin loan. 
 
When an entire class of collateral loses value, like mortgage bonds during the financial crisis in 2008, lenders issue a margin call. This caused bear stearns to fail and the Fed stepped in and started buying mortgage bonds. 
 
Since then treasuries are used, since treasury bonds are liquid and low volatility/low beta with values which don't fluctuate much (lol). 
 
Recently though treasury yields are soaring, which means the bonds used as collateral in the repo market are losing value quickly, triggering repo fails and margin calls again. Not good.

Zerohedge is hyping the MOVE index tonight without any context, so I thought I'd add more meat to the subject. 
 
The prior two times the MOVE index (bond volatility) shot through the roof was when the Fed was cutting rates to the floor. This time the MOVE index is soaring because they're hiking through the roof. 
 
The best buying opportunities in the stock market has been when the vix soars, which has also coincided with the Fed cutting/easing, which has also marked market bottoms in the past or pretty close to it as lower rates are bullish for P/E expansion and discounted cash flows (DCF). 
 
I'd still like to see that same cutting regime from the Fed to know brighter days are ahead. And that would likely cause a MOVE/VIX spike when it happens as it has before. We're not yet seeing that. 
 
Bond volatility is up for a different reason this time, and perhaps that reason (hiking) explains why the vix isn't tagging along the same way.

$TLT I completely disagree with the headline here, but the data is informative. Previous hiking and holding periods. 
 
Fintwit seems convinced the Fed is not only hiking at the fastest rate in history (true), but that afterwards, they're going to hold rates for the longest time in history. Historic data doesn't support this. 
 
The steeper the hike, the shorter the holding period. The closest comparison to today is the 83-84 and 88-89 period and they only held rates at the high for 1 - 3 months before cutting again. The only time they've held rates higher for longer was when they gradually increased them over a period of years.
